newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian peso falls in daily devaluation program.
newsitem.headline: Colombian peso falls in daily devaluation program.

text.p: Colombia's peso was pushed down 0.33 pesos to 998.33 to the dollar as the central bank altered its daily floating exchange rate band, interbank traders said.

Greenbacks continued to flow into the market but in more limited quantities than on previous days. The peso's downward trend of late has been mostly due to the central bank's crawling peg devaluation program -- which enables it to fix a daily band for peso-dollar movement -- rather than the free supply and demand of dollars, traders said.

Nevertheless, the central bank will not achieve its 1996 target of a 13.5 percent devaluation in the peso. Hefty influxes of export earnings, foreign investment and dollar-denominated debt have meant that the peso devaluation in the year to date has been less than 3 percent.
Traders reported 128 trades worth a total $135.7 million. The peso hit an intraday low of 998.5 and closed at the high of 998.33. The day's average was 998.35.
